questions.question: How many questions are on the Canadian Citizenship test?
How much time do you have to do the Canadian Citizenship Test?
How many questions do you need to answer correctly, in order to pass the Canadian Citizenship Test?
questions.feedback: In order for you to pass the test, you need to get at least 15 correct answers (75%).

questions.question: What are the question formats in the Canadian Citizenship Test?
options: 3 true or false and short writing

questions.question: What are two other words that can be used instead of the words king or queen?
questions.feedback: Other words for a queen or king are a monarch or Sovereign. Canada has a constitution (a set of laws) and a monarch, so Canada is a constitutional monarchy.

questions.question: To whom do Canadians make the oath (promise) of citizenship?
questions.feedback: In Canada, when we make our oath of Citizenship, we are promising to be loyal to a person who represents all Canadians, King Charles the Third.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT another word used to refer to The King?
questions.feedback: The King is Canada's Head of State. Other words for a queen or king are a monarch or Sovereign.

questions.question: Who is the person who we make our oath to and represents all Canadians?
questions.feedback: In Canada, when we make our oath of Citizenship, we are promising to be loyal to a person who represents all Canadians, King Charles the Third.

questions.question: In order to become a Canadian Citizen, you have to provide proof that you speak and write in:
questions.feedback: In order to apply for Canadian citizenship, you must provide proof that you know how to speak and write in 1 of Canada's official languages (either English or French).

questions.question: Which one of the following is a source of the Canadian law?
questions.feedback: Canadian law comes from English common law, the civil code of France, and Great Britain.
options: 2 The civil code of the United States

questions.question: What does "Magna Carta" refer to?
questions.feedback: In 1215, the people in Great Britain signed a document which is known as the Magna Carta, or the Great Charter of Freedoms.

questions.question: Where was the "Magna Carta" signed?
questions.feedback: Magna Carta, or the Great Charter of Freedoms was signed in Great Britain (England), in 1215.

questions.question: When was The Great Charter of Freedoms (Magna Carta) signed?
questions.feedback: Magna Carta, or the Great Charter of Freedoms was signed in 1215.

questions.question: The Great Charter of Freedoms is also called:
questions.feedback: The Great Charter of Freedoms is also known as Magna Carta.

questions.question: All of them are included in the Great Charter of Freedom except for:
questions.feedback: Canadians enjoy four (4) fundamental freedoms: Freedom of conscience and religion, freedom of thought, belief, and opinion and expression, including freedom of speech and of the press, freedom of peaceful assembly, and freedom of association.

questions.question: What does Habeas Corpus refer to?
questions.feedback: Habeas corpus is the right to challenge unlawful detention by the state which means that if you are arrested by the police and you haven't done anything illegal, you can challenge the police. It has come from English common law.
options: 1 The right to challenge unlawful detention by the state
2 The right to live anywhere you want
3 The right to have your own thoughts and believes
4 The right for choosing your religion

questions.question: The "right to challenge unlawful detention by the state" is also know as:
questions.feedback: The right to challenge unlawful detention by the state is also known as Habeas corpus. This means that if you are arrested by the police and you haven't done anything illegal, you can challenge the police.

questions.question: What is the source of Habeas Corpus?
questions.feedback: Habeas corpus is the right to challenge unlawful detention by the state and it has come from English common law.

questions.question: The Constitution of Canada was amended in ____ to include the Charter of Rights and Freedoms.
questions.feedback: The Constitution of Canada was amended in 1982 by Queen Elizabeth II to establish the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms.

questions.question: Who declared the amended Constitution of Canada in 1982?
questions.feedback: The Constitution of Canada was amended in 1982 by Queen Elizabeth II to establish the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms.

questions.question: The two principles upon which Canada is founded are:
questions.feedback: Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms begins with the words "Whereas Canada is founded upon principles that recognize the supremacy of God and the rule of law." The Charter points out that religious traditions are really important for Canadians and
options: 1 The supremacy of God and the rule of law
2 The supremacy of God and mobility right
3 The rule of law and mobility right
4 The rule of law and multiculturalism

questions.question: Which of the following explains the "mobility rights" the best?
questions.feedback: Mobility Rights refers to the fact that Canadian citizens can live and work wherever they want, leave and come back to the country at any time, and apply for a passport.
options: 1 Canadians can live and work anywhere they choose in Canada, enter/leave the country freely, and apply for a passport.
2 Canadians can live and work anywhere they choose in Canada and enter/leave the country freely.
3 Canadians can enter and leave the country freely and apply for a passport.
4 Canadians can leave the country freely and apply for a passport.

questions.question: Which one is not included in the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms?
questions.feedback: Canadian citizens enjoy the following 4 rights: Mobility rights, Aboriginal people's rights, official language rights, minority language education rights, and multiculturalism.
options: 3 Official Language Rights and Minority Language Educational Rights

questions.question: English and French have equal status in Parliament and throughout the government
questions.feedback: Official Language Rights and Minority Language Educational Rights states that English and French are used equally both in Parliament and the government.

questions.question: Canadians can live and work anywhere they choose in Canada.
questions.feedback: Mobility Rights states that Canadian citizens can live and work wherever they want, leave and come back to the country at any time, and apply for a passport.

questions.question: The rights guaranteed in the Charter will adversely affect any treaty or other rights or freedom of Aboriginal peoples.
questions.feedback: Aboriginal Peoples' Rights states that The Charter of Rights and Freedoms will NOT change any agreements with Aboriginal Peoples.

questions.question: Canadians work hard to respect pluralism and live in harmony.
questions.feedback: Canada is a multicultural country. Canadians respect other beliefs and live in peace.

questions.question: ______ is a fundamental characteristic of the Canadian heritage and identity.
questions.feedback: Multiculturalism means that Canada is a multicultural country and Canadians respect other beliefs and live in peace.

questions.question: In Canada, men and women are not equal under the law.
questions.feedback: Men and women are equal in Canada under the law.

questions.question: Why can men and women get the same education in Canada?
questions.feedback: Men and women are equal in Canada under the law.
options: 1 Because men and women are equal under the law in Canada
2 Because Canada is a free country
3 Because education is free in Canada
4 Because people respect multiculturalism in Canada

questions.question: In Canada, forced marriage is:
questions.feedback: No one can force anybody to marry someone else (forced marriage) in Canada under the law.

questions.question: Which one is not an example of a crime in Canada?
questions.feedback: Honor Killings, Female genital mutilation, and Gender-based violence are illegal under the law in Canada.

questions.question: Which ones are three responsibilities of Canadian citizens?
questions.feedback: Obeying the law, taking responsibility for oneself and one's family, and serving on a jury are three of the six responsibilities of a Canadain Citizen.
options: 1 Obeying the law, taking responsibility for oneself and one's family, and serving on a jury
2 Being loyal to Canada, recycling all waste, and serving in the Canadian Forces
3 Buying Canadian products, owning your own house, and using less water
4 Learning both official languages, voting in elections, and belonging to a union

questions.question: Which one of the following is a responsibility of Canadian citizens?
questions.feedback: Obeying the law is one of the responsibilities of a Canadian citizen.

questions.question: Which one of the following is not a responsibility of Canadian citizens?
questions.feedback: There is no required military service in Canada.

questions.question: Serving on jury is:
questions.feedback: Serving on a jury is one of the responsibilities of a Canadian citizen.

questions.question: Who can disobey the law?
questions.feedback: In Canada, everyone has to obey the law regardless of their position. No person or group is above the law.

questions.question: Getting a job, taking care of one's family and working hard is:
questions.feedback: Taking responsibility for oneself and one's family is one of the responsibilities of a Canadian citizen.

questions.question: Individuals and governments are not regulated by laws and by arbitrary actions.
questions.feedback: Everyone has to obey the law regardless of their position. No person or group is above the law.

questions.question: What makes the justice system work?
questions.feedback: Serving on a jury is a privilege that makes the justice system work as it depends on impartial juries made up of citizens.

questions.question: When called to do so, serving on a jury is:
questions.feedback: When called to do so, you are legally required to serve on a jury.

questions.question: What is the importance of serving on a jury?
questions.feedback: Serving on a jury is a privilege that makes the justice system work as it depends on impartial juries made up of citizens.
options: 1 It makes the justice system work as a it depends on impartial juries made up of citizens
2 It makes the justice system work by eliminating the need of judges
3 You are given some extra rights

questions.question: Voting in elections is:
questions.feedback: Voting in federal, provincial or territorial, and local elections is a responsibility.

questions.question: Which one is not a kind of election in Canada?
questions.feedback: You can vote in three kinds of elections in Canada. Federal (for the whole country), Provincial or Territorial, and Local (for a municipality or city).

questions.question: Helping others in the community:
questions.feedback: Volunteering is an excellent way to gain useful skills and develop friends and contacts.
options: 1 is an excellent way to gain useful skills and develop friends and contacts
2 is an excellent way to protect Canada's natural and cultural heritage
3 is an excellent way to help justice system work
4 is an excellent way to contribute to personal dignity and self-respect

questions.question: Military service is compulsory in Canada
questions.feedback: There is no compulsory (mandatory) military service in Canada.

questions.question: Serving in the regular Canadian Forces is a noble way to contribute to Canada and an excellent career choice.
What does a jury do?
questions.feedback: A jury helps the judge to make decisions about whether the person who is on trial is guilty or not guilty.
options: 1 Helps the judge to make decisions about whether the person who is on trial is guilty or not
2 Serves in the regular Canadian forces to defend Canada
3 Volunteers in their local community to gain useful skills and develop friends and contacts
4 Learns both official languages to vote in elections

questions.question: Besides working in the military, what are some other ways to help Canada?
options: 1 By working in the Coast Guard or emergency services, or as a police officer or firefighter

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT considered a way to help Canada?
options: 2 Working in the Coast Guard or emergency services
4 Working as a police officer or a firefighter

questions.question: Canada is not the only Constitutional Monarchy in North America.
questions.feedback: Canada is the only constitutional monarchy in North America.

questions.question: What are the three countries in North America?
questions.feedback: There are three countries in North America: Canada, the United States of America (U.S.A.), and Mexico.
options: 4 The USA, The UK, and Canada

questions.question: The USA and Mexico also have a constitutional monarchy.
questions.feedback: Canada is the only constitutional monarchy in North America.

questions.question: What is an important expression in Canadian government?
questions.feedback: Peace, Order, and Good Government is an important expression in the Canadian government.

questions.question: Peace, Order and Good Government is a key phrase in Canada's original constitutional document.
questions.feedback: An important expression in the Canadian government is the commitment to Peace, Order, and Good Government.

questions.question: What is the name of Canada's original constitutional document?
questions.feedback: British North America Act is Canada's original constitutional document.

questions.question: What have poets and songwriters hailed Canada as?
questions.feedback: Poets and songwriters have referred to Canada as the The Great Dominion.

questions.question: What was the first expression ever used in 1867, in the British North America Act?
questions.feedback: An important and first expression in the Canadian government is the commitment to Peace, Order, and Good Government.

questions.question: When was the British North America Act created?
questions.feedback: British North America Act was Canada's original constitutional document created in 1867.

questions.question: Who were the founding peoples of Canada?
questions.feedback: There are 3 groups of people who helped to start Canada: The Aboriginal people, the French, and the British
options: 1 The Aboriginal people, the French, and the British
2 The Aboriginal, First Nations and Inuit
3 The French, the Spanish and the British
4 The Aboriginal people, the French, and the American

questions.question: Who were the first people to live in Canada?
questions.feedback: The Aboriginal peoples were the first people to live in Canada. They lived and worked in Canada long before the French or British came.

questions.question: What did King George III do in 1763?
questions.feedback: In the past, in 1763, King George III promised to allow the Aboriginal peoples to have the right to the land on which they lived. These were called territorial rights.
options: 1 He promised to allow the Aboriginal people to have the right to the land on which they lived.
2 He promised to allow the Aboriginal people to have the right to speak any language they want.
3 He promised to allow the Aboriginal people to have the right to create any art they want.
4 He promised to allow the Aboriginal people to have the right to farm.

questions.question: Territorial rights refer to:
questions.feedback: Territorial rights refer to King George III promising to allow the Aboriginal peoples to have the right to the land on which they lived.
options: 1 King George III promising to allow the Aboriginal people to have the right to the land on which they lived.
2 Queen Elizabeth II promising to allow the French people to have the right to the land on which they lived.
3 King George III promising to allow Canadians to have their own ideas, they can say anything they want and publish whatever they like.
4 Queen Elizabeth II promising to allow the British people to have the right to the land on which they lived.

questions.question: What are the three main groups of Aboriginal peoples?
questions.feedback: The term Aboriginal peoples refers to three groups: The Indian (First Nations People), The Inuit and The Métis

questions.question: What term began to be used instead of Indian in the 1970s?
questions.feedback: Indian refers to all Aboriginal people who are not Inuit or Métis. This word is no longer used very much. In the 1970s, the term First Nations began to be used instead.

questions.question: Where does about half of First Nations people live today?
questions.feedback: Today, about half of First Nations people live on reserve land. Reserve land is the land that the government legally owns.

questions.question: What does "The inuit" means in the Inuktitut language?
questions.feedback: The inuit, which means "the people" in the Inuktitut language, live in small communities across the Arctic.

questions.question: What percentage of the Aboriginal people in Canada are Inuit?
questions.feedback: About 65% of the Aboriginal people are first Nations, while 30% are Métis and 4% Inuit.

questions.question: Where does the Métis mostly live in Canada?
questions.feedback: The Métis people mostly live in the Prairie provinces (Alberta, Saskatchewan, and Manitoba).

questions.question: What is the Métis dialect called?
questions.feedback: The Métis speak English or French, but may also speak their own dialect, which is called Michif.

questions.question: How many First Nations communities are on reserve land?
questions.feedback: There are around 600 communities on reserve land and the other half live mainly in urban centres.

questions.question: What percentage of the Aboriginal people living in Canada are Métis?
questions.feedback: About 65% of the Aboriginal people are first Nations, while 30% are Métis and 4% inuit.

questions.question: What percentage of the Aboriginal people living in Canada are First Nations?
questions.feedback: About 65% of the Aboriginal people are first Nations, while 30% are Métis and 4% Inuit.

questions.question: What are Canada's two official languages?
questions.feedback: English and French are Canada's two official languages. The law states that the Federal government must have services in both English and French, throughout Canada.

questions.question: What are the people who speak English as a first language called?
questions.feedback: People who speak English as a first language are called Anglophones. There are about 18 million of them.

questions.question: What are the people who speak French as a first language called?
questions.feedback: People who speak French as a first language are called Francophones. There are about 7 million of them.

questions.question: Where does most Francophones live in Canada today?
questions.feedback: Most Francophones live in Quebec, but almost one million Francophones also live in Ontario, New Brunswick, and Manitoba.

questions.question: What is the only officially bilingual province?
questions.feedback: New Brunswick is the only officially bilingual province.

questions.question: Anglophones are:
questions.feedback: People who speak English as a first language are called Anglophones. There are about 18 million of them.
options: 1 People who speak English as a first language
2 People who speak French as a first language
3 People who speak Albanian as a first language
4 People who speak English as a second language

questions.question: New Brunswick is not the only officially bilingual province in Canada.
questions.feedback: New Brunswick is the only officially bilingual province.

questions.question: Most of the Francophones live in Quebec
questions.feedback: Most Francophones live in Quebec.

questions.question: Which provinces are in the Maritimes?
questions.feedback: The provinces on the eastern side of Canada - Nova Scotia, New Brunswick and Prince Edward Island - are called the Maritime Provinces.
options: 1 Nova Scotia, New Brunswick, and Prince Edward Island
2 Ontario, Nova Scotia, New Brunswick, and Prince Edward Island
3 Ontario, Nova Scotia, Quebec, and Prince Edward Island
4 Ontario, Nova Scotia, Quebec, New Brunswick

questions.question: Who are the Acadians?
questions.feedback: The Acadians are the descendants of French colonists who began settling in what are now the Maritime provinces in 1604.
options: 1 They are descendants of French colonists who came to Canada in 1604
2 They are descendants of English colonists who came to Canada in 1763
3 They are descendants of English colonists who came to Canada in 1604
4 They are descendants of French colonists who came to Canada in 1763

questions.question: Where did French colonists who came to Canada settle in?
questions.feedback: The descendants of French colonists began settling in what are now the Maritime provinces.

questions.question: Between 1755 and 1763, the Acadians were forced to leave Canada, and go to Britain, France, and another British colonies. This was called:
questions.feedback: There was a war between Britain and France between 1755 and 1763. During this time, more than two thirds of the Acadians living in this part of Canada were forced to leave Canada, and go to Britain, France, or another British colony. This is called the Great Upheaval.

questions.question: Who are the Quebecers?
questions.feedback: Quebecers are the people of Quebec, the vast majority French-speaking.

questions.question: What did the federal government agree to in 2006?
questions.feedback: In 2006, the House of Commons agreed that Quebecers, including the French-speaking Quebecois, form a nation within a united Canada.
options: 1 Agreed Quebecers to form a nation within a united Canada
2 Agreed Anglophones to form a nation within a united Canada
3 Agreed Francophones to form a nation outside a united Canada
4 Agreed First Nations to form a nation within a united Canada

questions.question: Where have most immigrants come from since the 1970s?
questions.feedback: Since the 1970s, most immigrants have come from Asian countries.

questions.question: Canada has a multicultural society.
questions.feedback: Canada is a multicultural society and is referred to as a land of immigrants.

questions.question: Languages other than English and French are widely spoken in Canadian homes.
questions.feedback: Languages other than English and French are widely spoken in Canadian homes. Chinese languages like Mandarin and Cantonese, are the second most-spoken at home, after English, in two of Canada's biggest cities.

questions.question: In Vancouver, 13% of the population speaks Chinese languages at home.
questions.feedback: In Vancouver, 13% of the population speaks Chinese languages at home; in Toronto, the number is 7%.

questions.question: What is the largest religious affiliation in Canada?
questions.feedback: The largest religious affiliation is Catholic, followed by various Protestant churches.

questions.question: Gay and lesbian Canadians, enjoy the full protection of and equal treatment under the law.
questions.feedback: Gay and lesbian Canadians are protected under the law; they are treated the same as other Canadians; they can get married.

questions.question: Gay and lesbian Canadians can get married under the law.
questions.feedback: In Canada, the laws treat both gay and lesbian Canadians the same as other Canadians. They are protected under the law. They can get married.

questions.question: Who were Cree, Dene, Iroquois, Sioux, and Inuit?
questions.feedback: Cree, Dene, Iroquois, Sioux, Inuit were names of some native groups.

questions.question: Who came from Iceland to the eastern part of Canada 1000 years ago?
questions.feedback: One thousand years ago, Vikings from Iceland came to Newfoundland and Labrador.

questions.question: Who was the first person to draw a map of Canada's east coast?
questions.feedback: John Cabot was the first to draw a map of the east coast of Canada.

questions.question: Who made three voyages across the Atlantic Ocean between 1534 and 1542 to claim the land of Canada for the King of France?
questions.feedback: Jacques Cartier made three voyages across the Atlantic Ocean between 1534 and 1542. He was the first European to explore the land where Quebec City and Montreal are today.

questions.question: The name "Canada" which comes from the word "Kanata" means _____ in the Iroquoian language.
questions.feedback: The name "Canada" comes from the word, "Kanata", which is the Huron-Iroquois word for village.

questions.question: Which Aboriginal group was (historically) the enemy of the Algonquin, Montagnais and Huron?
questions.feedback: Champlain joined his colony with some Aboriginal groups: the Algonquin, Montagnais and Huron. These groups had a history of being enemies with another Aboriginal group, the Iroquois.

questions.question: When was the Hudson's Bay Company allowed to look for fur in all of the land that had water flowing into Hudson Bay?
questions.feedback: In 1670, King Charles II allowed the Hudson's Bay Company to look for fur in all of the land that had water flowing into Hudson Bay.

questions.question: What did King Charles II allow the Hudson's Bay Company to look for in 1670?
questions.feedback: King Charles II allowed the Hudson's Bay Company to look for fur in all of the land that had water flowing into Hudson Bay.

questions.question: Which company did King Charles II allow to look for fur in 1670?
questions.feedback: In 1670, King Charles II of England decided that the fur trade company called the Hudson's Bay Company was allowed to look for fur in all of the land that had water flowing into Hudson Bay.

questions.question: Who were the voyageurs, or coureurs des bois?
questions.feedback: The people who worked for the fur trade companies from Montreal were from France. They traveled by canoe and carried trade goods and supplies to exchange for furs. They were called voyageurs and coureurs des bois.
options: 1 Men from Montreal who traveled by canoe and carried trade goods and supplies to exchange for furs.
2 Men from Toronto who traveled by canoe and carried trade goods and supplies to exchange for furs.
3 Men from Montreal who traveled by canoe and carried trade goods and supplies to exchange for leather.
4 Men from Toronto who traveled by canoe and carried trade goods and supplies to exchange for leather.

questions.question: Where did the British defeated the French in 1759?
questions.feedback: In 1759, the British defeated the French at an important battle. This battle was near Quebec City, on the Plains of Abraham.

questions.question: Who was a great hero of New France who fought against the British and won many battles?
questions.feedback: Pierre Le Moyne was a great hero of New France. He was also called Sieur d'Iberville. He fought against the British and won many battles. He lived during the late 17th and early 18th centuries.

questions.question: Who helped the Loyalists to move from the United States to Nova Scotia and Quebec in 1782 and 1783?
questions.feedback: Sir Guy Carleton was British. He was also called Lord Dorchester. He helped the people who lived in the United States and wanted to stay loyal to the British queen. He helped these Loyalists move from the United States to Nova Scotia and Quebec in 1782 and 1783.

questions.question: Who was defeated during the battle of the Plains of Abraham?
questions.feedback: In the 1700s, France and Britain battled to decide who would control North America. In 1759, the British defeated the French at an important battle near Quebec City, on the Plains of Abraham.

questions.question: What was the name of Quebec before 1759?
questions.feedback: After the war, Great Britain renamed the colony the "Province of Quebec".

questions.question: Who were the habitants or Canadiens?
questions.feedback: The French-speaking Catholic people, known as habitants or Canadiens, tried hard to keep their way of life in the British Empire which was English-speaking and ruled by Protestants.
options: 1 The French-speaking Catholic people in the Province of Quebec
2 The English-speaking Catholic people in the Province of Quebec
3 The French-speaking Protestant people in the Province of Quebec
4 The English-speaking Protestant people in the Province of Quebec

questions.question: The British parliament passed laws to help the French-speaking Catholic people to govern the French Roman Catholic people in Quebec. Also known as Quebec Act.
questions.feedback: In 1774, the British parliament passed laws to help the French-speaking Catholic people to govern the French Roman Catholic people in Quebec. These laws were called the Quebec Act. It allowed religious freedom for Catholics and allowed them to work in government jobs. It established British criminal law and French civil law.

questions.question: What is the Quebec Act?
questions.feedback: The British parliament passed laws to help the French-speaking Catholic people to govern the French Roman Catholic people in Quebec in 1774. These laws were called the Quebec Act. It allowed religious freedom for Catholics and allowed them to work in government jobs.
options: 1 The laws passed by the British government to help the French-speaking Catholic people to govern the French Roman Catholic people in Quebec
2 The laws passed by the France government to help the British-speaking Catholic people to govern the French Roman Catholic people in Quebec
3 The laws passed by the France government to help the French-speaking Catholic people to govern the French Roman Catholic people in Quebec
4 The laws passed by the British government to help the British-speaking Catholic people to govern the French Roman Catholic people in Quebec

questions.question: Who were the Loyalists, also known as United Empire Loyalists?
questions.feedback: In 1776, more than 40,000 people wanted to continue to be loyal to the Queen. So, they ran away from the United States during and after the American Revolution, to settle in Nova Scotia and Quebec.
options: 1 Settlers who came from the United States during and after the American Revolution
2 Settlers who came from Nova Scotia during and after the American Revolution
3 Settlers who came from West Africa during and after the American Revolution
4 Settlers who came from Quebec during and after the American Revolution

questions.question: The Loyalists, or United Empire Loyalists were people who decided to become independent from Britain
questions.feedback: The loyalists wanted to continue to be loyal to the Queen. So, they ran away from the United States during and after the American Revolution, to settle in Nova Scotia and Quebec.

questions.question: Who led thousands of Loyalist Mohawk Indians into Canada?
questions.feedback: Joseph Brant led thousands of Loyalist Mohawk Indians into Canada. These loyalists came from Dutch, German, British, Scandinavian, Aboriginal, and other origins, and had different religious backgrounds.

questions.question: How many Black Loyalists came north to live in Canada?
questions.feedback: About 3,000 Black Loyalists came north to live in Canada.

questions.question: Freetown, in Sierra Leone was started in 1792 when some Black Nova Scotians left Canada.
questions.feedback: In 1792, some Black Nova Scotians left Canada to establish the city of Freetown in the country of Sierra Leone, which is in West Africa.

questions.question: When was the first elected representative assembly?
questions.feedback: In 1758, the first representative assembly was elected in Halifax.

questions.question: What did The Constitutional Act of 1791 do?
questions.feedback: The Constitutional Act of 1791 divided the Province of Quebec into Upper Canada and Lower Canada.
options: 1 Divided the Province of Quebec into Upper Canada and Lower Canada
2 Elected the first representative assembly in Halifax
3 Debated whether to use both French and English
4 Elected the first representative assembly in Prince Edward

questions.question: What province did Upper Canada become? Was it Protestant or Catholic?
questions.feedback: Upper Canada later became Ontario, and it had mostly English-speaking people who were Protestant and were loyal to Britain.

questions.question: What province did Lower Canada become? Was it Protestant or Catholic?
questions.feedback: Lower Canada later became Quebec, and it had mostly French-speaking people who were Catholic.

questions.question: What was the name for the provinces of Upper Canada, Lower Canada and the Atlantic colonies?
questions.feedback: The name for the provinces of Upper Canada, Lower Canada, and the Atlantic colonies was British North America.

questions.question: The Constitutional Act gave both Upper and Lower Canada the right to have elections.
questions.feedback: The Constitutional Act gave both Upper and Lower Canada the right to have elections, to elect people into a legislative assembly.

questions.question: What is the Canadian Constitution?
questions.feedback: The system of laws and conventions by which our country governs itself, is known as The Canadian Constitution.
options: 1 The Canadian Constitution is a system of laws and conventions by which our country governs itself.
2 The Canadian Constitution is a collection of arts and culture by which our country represents itself.
3 The Canadian Constitution is a collection of maps and guides by which our country defends itself.
4 The Canadian Constitution is a collection of people and leaders by which our country represents itself.

questions.question: Who helped Upper Canada make the decision to stop slavery in 1793?
questions.feedback: In 1793, Lieutenant Governor John Graves Simcoe helped Upper Canada to make the decision to stop slavery.

questions.question: Who was the first Lieutenant Governor of Canada and founder of the city of York, now known as Toronto?
questions.feedback: Lieutenant Governor John Graves Simcoe was a Loyalist military officer and the first Lieutenant Governor of Canada. He was also the founder of the city of York, which is now called Toronto.

questions.question: Thousands of slaves escaped the United States by following the North Star to travel north to Canada.
The way of escape that thousands of slaves used as they escaped from the United States to Canada was called the Underground Railroad.
questions.feedback: Thousands of slaves escaped the United States by following the North Star to travel north to Canada. People who didn’t agree with slavery helped the slaves by hiding them in their homes. This way of escape was called the Underground Railroad.

questions.question: Mary Ann (Shadd) Carey was the publisher of a weekly newspaper called The Provincial Freeman and wanted to end slavery in the United States.
questions.feedback: Mary Ann (Shadd) Carey wanted to end slavery in the United States. She was the publisher of a weekly newspaper called The Provincial Freeman. This newspaper had information about how to stop slavery.

questions.question: When did the Montreal stock exchange open?
questions.feedback: The first financial institutions opened in the late 18th and early 19th centuries. The Montreal Stock Exchange opened in 1832.

questions.question: What did the first companies in Canada compete for?
questions.feedback: The first companies in Canada competed for the fur trade.

questions.question: What did the United States do in June 1812?
questions.feedback: The United States believed it would be easy to conquer Canada, and so they attacked Canada in June 1812.

questions.question: Who was Chief Tecumseh?
questions.feedback: Chief Tecumseh was an Aboriginal person who helped to defend Canada when Canada was fighting against the United States.
options: 1 An Aboriginal person who helped to defend Canada
2 An Aboriginal person who helped to defend the USA
3 A British person who helped to defend Canada
4 A British person who helped to defend the USA

questions.question: What city did Major-General Sir Isaac Brock capture?
questions.feedback: Major-General Sir Isaac Brock captured the city of Detroit but was later killed near Niagara Falls.

questions.question: When did the United States attack Canada?

questions.question: How are Members of Parliament chosen?
questions.feedback: Voting must be by secret ballot in Canada. No one should look at how you are voting.

questions.question: In Canada, are you obliged to tell other people how you voted?
questions.feedback: You can discuss your vote with whomever you choose, but no one has the right to insist that you tell them how you voted.

questions.question: Can you still vote if your name is not on the voters' list, on the day of the election?
questions.feedback: Even if you choose not to be listed in the National Register of Electors or do not receive a voter information card, you can still be added to the voters’ list at any time, including on election day.

questions.question: The voter information card tells you when and where you can vote
questions.feedback: The card sent by National Register of Electors, tells you when and where you can vote

questions.question: In Canada, your vote is secret
questions.feedback: In Canada, your vote is secret. You will make your vote behind a screen so that others cannot see you

questions.question: You can see the results on television or online at Elections Canada.
questions.feedback: When election day is over, the polling stations close. Every ballot is counted and the results are published. You can see the results on television or online at Elections Canada.

questions.question: Who is responsible for conducting an election?
questions.feedback: A Returning Officer is the person who is responsible to conduct the election in an electoral division.

questions.question: The table inside the voting place where a voter receives his/her ballot is called a Voting Place.
questions.feedback: The table inside the voting place where a voter receives his/her ballot is called a voting station.

questions.question: Someone will come to your door before a provincial election. They will ask for the names of eligible voters who live in your home. What are they called?
questions.feedback: An Enumerator is the person who goes door to door collecting names of eligible voters for the voters list.

questions.question: What is a ballot?
questions.feedback: A ballot is the piece of papera that voters use to vote.
options: 2 The location voters go to vote

questions.question: What is a municipal electoral area called?
questions.feedback: For municipal elections, each municipality (city or town) is divided into 14 areas. These municipal areas are called wards.

questions.question: What is a provincial electoral area called?
questions.feedback: For provincial elections, each province or territory is divided into different areas called electoral divisions.

questions.question: What is a federal electoral area called?
questions.feedback: For federal elections, the country of Canada is divided into 308 areas (the official handbook indicates the number of electoral districts as 308, as it was last updated in 2012. However, Canada currently has 338 federal electoral districts). Each area has some candidates. People in the same area have the same choice of candidates. These federal areas are called constituencies or ridings.

questions.question: What is the role of the courts in Canada?
options: 1 The role of the courts in Canada is to settle disputes
2 The role of the courts in Canada is to issue fines

questions.question: Who has to follow Canadian laws?
questions.feedback: Canadian laws must be followed by everyone, including judges, politicians and the police.

questions.question: Prisons have an essential role in punishing criminals and deterring crime.
In Canada, are you allowed to question the police about their service or conduct?
questions.feedback: In Canada, you're allowed to question the police about their service or conduct

questions.question: Which two provinces have provincial police forces?
questions.feedback: Ontario and Quebec have provincial police forces.

questions.question: The Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP) enforces federal laws.
questions.feedback: The RCMP enforces federal laws

questions.question: Which of the following is not a type of police in Canada?
questions.feedback: There are different types of police in Canada. (Municipal) police departments, provincial police forces and the RCMP.

questions.question: What is due process?
questions.feedback: The Canadian justice system has a very organized way of making sure that everyone has just and fair treatment, with all of their legal rights. This is called due process.
options: 1 A very organized way of making sure that everyone has a just and fair treatment, with all of their legal rights.
2 A random way of making sure that some people have a just and fair treatment, with all of their legal rights.

questions.question: When someone is accused of committing a crime, the justice system must believe that they are innocent, until there is enough proof to show that they are guilty of the crime.
questions.feedback: This is called presumption of innocence.

questions.question: Which of the following is Canada's legal system not based on?
questions.feedback: Canada's legal system is based on the rule of law, freedom under the law, democratic principles, and due process.

questions.question: What is Canada's highest court called?
questions.feedback: Canada's highest court is called the Supreme Court of Canada.

questions.question: In which of the following are small offences not discussed?
questions.feedback: Smaller offences can be discussed at provincial courts, family courts, and traffic courts, but not the Supreme Court.

questions.question: Where are civil cases involving small sums of money settled?
questions.feedback: Civil cases involving small sums (amounts) of money are settled at small claims courts.

questions.question: Legal aid services are available for free (or low cost) if you cannot pay for a lawyer.
questions.feedback: Lawyers can help you with legal problems and in court. There are free (or low cost) legal aid services available if you cannot pay for a lawyer.

questions.question: Since when has Canada been a constitutional monarchy?
questions.feedback: Canada has been a constitutional monarchy since 1867 (Confederation).

questions.question: When did Queen Elizabeth II’s reign as Canada’s queen begin?
questions.feedback: Queen Elizabeth II was the Queen of Canada from 1952 until her passing in 2022.

questions.question: The Crown is a symbol of government: Parliament, the legislatures, the courts, police services and the armed forces.
When was the flag that we use in Canada today first raised on a flagpole?
questions.feedback: The Canadian flag we use today was first raised on a flagpole on February 15, 1965.

questions.question: Where did the red-white-red pattern of the flag come from?
questions.feedback: The red-white-red pattern comes from the flag of the Royal Military College, Kingston, founded in 1876.

questions.question: What is Canada's most well known and most respected symbol?
questions.feedback: Canada's most well known and most respected symbol is the maple leaf.

questions.question: What does the Peace Tower help Canadians to remember?
questions.feedback: In 1927, the Peace Tower was completed to remember the soldiers who died in World War I.
options: 1 The soldiers who died in World War I

questions.question: What animal is on the five-cent coin?
questions.feedback: The beaver is on the five-cent coin.

questions.question: Who donated the National Hockey League (NHL) championship Stanley Cup?
questions.feedback: The Stanley Cup was donated by Lord Stanley, the Governor General, in 1892.

questions.question: Adrienne Clarkson was the first Governor General of Asian origin.
What is the second most popular sport in Canada?
questions.feedback: Canadian football is the second most popular sport in Canada.

questions.question: What is the most popular sport in Canada?
questions.feedback: Canada's most popular spectator sport is Hockey, which also is the country's national winter sport.

questions.question: What is Canada's national winter sport?
questions.feedback: Hockey is Canada's national winter sport.

questions.question: What is a popular ice game introduced by Canada's Scottish pioneers?
questions.feedback: Curling is a popular ice game introduced by Canada's Scottish pioneers.

questions.question: What is the official summer sport in Canada which was also first played by Aboriginals?
questions.feedback: The official summer sport is lacrosse. It was first played by Aboriginals.

questions.question: Which sport has the most registered players of any game in Canada?
questions.feedback: Soccer has the most registered players of any game in Canada.

questions.question: What are the two official languages of Canada?
questions.feedback: English and French are the two official languages and are important symbols of Canadian identity.

questions.question: When was the Official Languages Act passed by parliament?
questions.feedback: The Official Languages Act was passed by Parliament in 1969.

questions.question: The Official Languages Act establishes equality between English and French in Parliament and the Government of Canada
questions.feedback: The Official Languages Act was passed by Parliament in 1969. It establishes equality between English and French in Parliament, the Government of Canada, and institutions that have to obey the Official Languages Act.

questions.question: The Official Languages Act promotes the English language in the Canadian society.
questions.feedback: The Official Languages Act was passed to promote equality of English and French in Canadian society.

questions.question: Where was O Canada first sung?
questions.feedback: O Canada was proclaimed as the National Anthem in 1980. It was first sung in Quebec City in 1880.

questions.question: How many versions of O Canada are there?
questions.feedback: There are three versions of the National Anthem: English, French and bilingual (part of the anthem is sung in English, part is sung in French).

questions.question: Why would you play the Royal Anthem of Canada?
questions.feedback: The Royal Anthem of Canada, can be played or sung on any occasion when Canadians wish to honour the Sovereign.

questions.question: What are three groups of awards that honour Canadians?
questions.feedback: Awards honour outstanding citizens and are divided in the following groups: orders, decorations, and medals.

questions.question: When was the Order of Canada started?
questions.feedback: The Order of Canada was started in 1967, one hundred years after Confederation.

questions.question: What is the highest honour that Canadians can receive?
questions.feedback: The Victoria Cross is the highest honour that can be given to a Canadian.

questions.question: The Victoria Cross is given for a brave action or self-sacrifice or extremely loyal service to Canada during war.
Ninety-six Canadians have received the Victoria Cross since 1854.
What does the Latin phrase "A Mari Usque Ad Mare" mean?
questions.feedback: The national motto (expression) is A Mari Usque Ad Mare. This is a Latin expression which means from sea to sea.

questions.question: When did Canada start free trade with the United States?
questions.feedback: In 1988, Canada started free trade with the United States.

questions.question: Who are the three members of NAFTA (North American Free Trade Agreement)?
questions.feedback: In 1994, Mexico, U.S.A. and Canada became partners in the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA).

questions.question: Canada's economy includes which three main industries?
questions.feedback: Service, manufacturing and natural resource industries are the three main industries in Canada's economy.
options: 1 Service, manufacturing and natural resource industries
3 Entertainment, manufacturing and natural resource industries

questions.question: What percentage of Canadians currently have jobs in service industries?
questions.feedback: More than 75% of working Canadians now have jobs in service industries.

questions.question: Which country is Canada's largest international trading partner?
questions.feedback: Our largest international trading partner is the United States.

questions.question: Many of Canada's exports are natural resource commodities.
Which country is the United States' largest trading partner?
questions.feedback: Canada has a close relationship with the United States. Canada is the U.S.A.'s largest trading partner, and the U.S.A. is Canada's largest trading partner.

questions.question: What percentage of the goods that Canada exports go to the United States?
questions.feedback: Over 3/4 (75%) of Canada's exports go to the U.S.A. Canada and the U.S.A. have the largest bilateral trading relationship in the world.

questions.question: Which two countries have the largest bilateral trading relationship in the world?
questions.feedback: Canada and the U.S.A. have the largest bilateral trading relationship in the world.
options: 3 The United Kingdom and the U.S.A

questions.question: Canada is the _____ largest country on earth.
questions.feedback: Canada is the second-largest country on earth; it has 10 million square kilometres.

questions.question: Which of the following does not border Canada?
questions.feedback: Canada borders with the Pacific Ocean to the west, the Atlantic Ocean to the east, and the Arctic Ocean to the north.
options: 1 The Indian Ocean to the south
2 The Pacific Ocean to the west
3 The Atlantic Ocean to the east
4 The Arctic Ocean to the north

questions.question: What is on the southern edge of Canada?
questions.feedback: The southern edge of Canada is the boundary between the U.S.A. and Canada.

questions.question: Newfoundland and Labrador, Prince Edward Island, Nova Scotia, New Brunswick are referred to as the:
questions.feedback: They are in the The Atlantic Region and are referred to as the Atlantic Provinces.

questions.question: Manitoba, Saskatchewan, Alberta are referred to as the:
questions.feedback: The Prairie Provinces are Manitoba, Saskatchewan, Alberta.

questions.question: Which two provinces are in Central Canada?
questions.feedback: The Quebec and Ontario provinces are in Central Canada

questions.question: What is the population of Canada?
questions.feedback: Canada has a population of about 34 million people.

questions.question: Who chose Ottawa to be the capital of Canada?
questions.feedback: In 1857, Queen Victoria chose Ottawa to be the capital of Canada.

questions.question: Queen Victoria is the great-great-grandmother of Queen Elizabeth II.
What is Canada's fourth largest metropolitan area?
questions.feedback: Ottawa is Canada's fourth-largest metropolitan area.

questions.question: What is the area around Ottawa, including Ottawa, called?
questions.feedback: The area around Ottawa, including Ottawa, is called the National Capital Region.

questions.question: Ottawa's Rideau Canal is a tourist attraction in Toronto.
questions.feedback: Ottawa's Rideau Canal is a tourist attraction in Ottawa and a place to go ice skating in winter. It used to be a military waterway.

questions.question: How many provinces and territories does Canada have?
questions.feedback: Canada has ten provinces and three territories.

questions.question: What is the capital of Canada?
questions.feedback: Ottawa is the capital of Canada. Toronto is the capital of Ontario.

questions.question: Toronto is the capital of Canada.
questions.feedback: Ottawa is the capital of Canada. Toronto is the capital of Ontario.

questions.question: What is the capital city of Ontario?
questions.feedback: Toronto is the capital of Ontario. Ottawa is the capital of Canada.

questions.question: What is the capital city of Manitoba?
questions.feedback: Winnipeg is the capital city of Manitoba.

questions.question: What is the capital city of Nova Scotia?
questions.feedback: Halifax is the capital city of Nova Scotia.

questions.question: What is the capital city of British Columbia?
questions.feedback: Victoria is the capital city of British Columbia.

questions.question: What is the capital city of Yukon?
questions.feedback: Whitehorse is the capital city of Yukon.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a type of industry common in the Atlantic Provinces?
questions.feedback: The Atlantic Provinces have natural resources like fishing, farming, and forestry.

questions.question: Which province is in the most easterly part of North America?
questions.feedback: Newfoundland and Labrador is the most easterly part in North America, and it has its own time zone.

questions.question: Which province has its own time zone?
questions.feedback: Newfoundland and Labrador has its own time zone and is the most easterly part in North America.

questions.question: Which province is the smallest province?
questions.feedback: Prince Edward Island (PEI) is the smallest province.

questions.question: What is PEI NOT known for?
questions.feedback: PEI is known for its beaches, red soil and agriculture, especially potatoes.

questions.question: What is the name of the longest bridge in Canada, which is 13 km long?
questions.feedback: PEI is connected to the mainland by the longest bridge in Canada, called the Confederation Bridge.

questions.question: Nova Scotia has the largest population out of all the Atlantic provinces.
questions.feedback: Nova Scotia is the Atlantic province with the biggest population.

questions.question: What is the capital of Nova Scotia?
questions.feedback: Nova Scotia capital is Halifax.

questions.question: Nova Scotian culture comes from Celtic and Gaelic traditions.
What mountain range is New Brunswick in?
questions.feedback: New Brunswick is in the Appalachian Range.

questions.question: Who founded New Brunswick?
questions.feedback: New Brunswick was founded by the United Empire Loyalists.

questions.question: What is the capital of New Brunswick?
questions.feedback: The New Brunswick capital is Fredericton.

questions.question: What makes New Brunswick different from other provinces and territories?
questions.feedback: New Brunswick is the only officially bilingual province.
options: 2 It has its own time zone

questions.question: More than half of the people in Canada live in Central Canada.
What provinces are located in Central Canada?
questions.feedback: Central Canada includes the cities and towns near the Great Lakes and the St. Lawrence River in southern Quebec and Ontario.

questions.question: Central Canada known for the industrial and manufacturing heartland.
questions.feedback: Central Canada is the industrial and manufacturing heartland. Together, Quebec and Ontario produce more than 75% of all of Canada's manufactured goods.

questions.question: What language do more than 75% of Quebecois residents speak as their first language?
questions.feedback: More than 75% speak French as their first language in Quebec.

questions.question: Which of the following is not one of the important industries in Quebec?
questions.feedback: The important industries are forestry, energy and mining in Quebec.

questions.question: What is Quebec's capital city?
questions.feedback: Montreal is famous for its cultural diversity, but Quebec City is Quebec's capital.

questions.question: What is the world's second largest French-speaking city?
questions.feedback: Montreal is Canada's second-largest city and the second-largest mainly French-speaking city in the world after Paris.

questions.question: How many people live in Ontario?
questions.feedback: Ontario has more than 12 million people

questions.question: More people live in Quebec than Ontario.
questions.feedback: Ontario has more than 12 million people, on the other hand, Quebec has a population of nearly 8 million people.

questions.question: What is the largest city in Canada?
questions.feedback: Toronto is the largest city in Canada. It is also Canada's financial centre.

questions.question: Who founded Ontario?
questions.feedback: Ontario was founded by the United Empire Loyalists.

questions.question: There are five Great Lakes located between Ontario and the United States.
questions.feedback: There are five Great Lakes located between Ontario and the United States: Lake Ontario, Lake Erie, Lake Huron, Lake Michigan and Lake Superior.

questions.question: Which of the Great Lakes is the largest freshwater lake in the world?
questions.feedback: Lake Superior is the largest freshwater lake in the world.

questions.question: What is the capital of Manitoba?
questions.feedback: Winnipeg is the capital of Manitoba, and it has the largest population of all the cities in Manitoba.

questions.question: What cultures or communities does Manitoba have?
questions.feedback: St. Boniface in Winnipeg's has the largest Francophone community. Also, 14% of Manitobans having Ukrainian ancestors.

questions.question: Manitoba has the largest Aboriginal population of any province.
questions.feedback: With over 15% of the population being Aboriginal,  Manitoba has the largest Aboriginal population of any province.

questions.question: Saskatchewan was known as the breadbasket of the world, or the wheat province.
questions.feedback: Saskatchewan was once known as the breadbasket of the world and the wheat province. It has over 40% of the arable land (land that is good for growing crops) in Canada.

questions.question: What is the capital of Saskatchewan?
questions.feedback: Regina is the capital of Saskatchewan.

questions.question: The Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP) has a training academy in Alberta.
questions.feedback: The Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP) has a training academy in Saskatchewan.

questions.question: Which province has the largest population in the Prairies?
questions.feedback: Alberta is the Prairie province which has the most people.

questions.question: Where did Alberta get it's name?
questions.feedback: The province got its name from the fourth daughter of Queen Victoria; Princess Louise Caroline Alberta.
options: 1 Princess Louise Caroline Alberta, daughter of Queen Victoria
2 Princess Louise Caroline Alberta, daughter of Queen Elizabeth II
3 Princess Louise Caroline Alberta, daughter of King George V
4 Princess Louise Caroline Alberta, daughter of King Charles I

questions.question: Which one is one of Alberta's national parks?
Alberta is the largest producer of oil and gas in Canada.
What is Canada's largest and busiest port?
questions.feedback: The Port of Vancouver is Canada's largest and busiest port

questions.question: What is British Columbia's biggest industry?
questions.feedback: Half of all the goods produced in BC are forestry products, including lumber, newsprint, and pulp and paper products.

questions.question: What is British Columbia's biggest ethnic community?
questions.feedback: BC has large Asian communities, and Chinese and Punjabi are the most-spoken languages in the cities, after English.

questions.question: What is the capital city of British Columbia?
questions.feedback: The capital of BC is Victoria.

questions.question: The North is also called The Land of the Midnight Sun, because in the summer daylight can last up to 24 hours.
questions.feedback: The North is sometimes called the Land of the Midnight Sun because, in the middle of summer, daylight can last up to 24 hours.

questions.question: How much of Canada's land mass does the North take up?
questions.feedback: The Northwest Territories, Nunavut, and Yukon contain one-third of Canada's landmass.

questions.question: What kind of art is made in the North and sold in Canada and around the world?
questions.feedback: Inuit art is sold throughout Canada and around the world.

questions.question: What happened in the 1890s in the Yukon territory?
questions.feedback: In the 1890s, during the Gold Rush, thousands of miners came to the Yukon Territory for gold.

questions.question: What is the highest mountain in Canada?
questions.feedback: Mount Logan is located in the Yukon. It is the highest mountain in Canada.

questions.question: What is the capital city of the Yukon territory?
questions.feedback: Whitehorse is the capital of Yukon.

questions.question: What is an important part of Yukon's economy?
questions.feedback: Mining is an important part of the economy of Yukon.

questions.question: The Northwest Territories were originally made up in 1870, using land from Rupert's land.
What is the capital of the Northwest Territories?
questions.feedback: The capital of the Northwest Territories is Yellowknife.

questions.question: Yellowknife is called the diamond capital of North America.
What group makes up more than half of the population of Northwest Territories?
questions.feedback: More than half of the population in the Northwest Territories are Aboriginal (Dene, Inuit, Métis).

questions.question: Nunavut means "our land" in Inuktitut.
questions.feedback: Nunavut means our land in Inuktitut.

questions.question: What is the capital of Nunavut?
questions.feedback: The capital is Iqaluit, which used to be called Frobisher Bay.

questions.question: What percentage of the Nunavut population is Inuit?
questions.feedback: The Nunavut population is about 85% Inuit.
